authors: Lucy Mae Beers For Daily Mail Australia
description: A man has been captured standing up out of his wheelchair after Roger Federer hit an unbelievable shot at the Australian Open in Melbourne on Thursday night.
title: Roger Federer fan is so excited he gets up out of his WHEELCHAIR - but the Swiss star is still knocked out of the Australian Open by Novak Djokovic
title_page: Roger Federer fan is so excited he gets up out of his WHEELCHAIR - but the Swiss star is still knocked out of the Australian Open by Novak DjokovicÂ  | Daily Mail Online
text:
A man has stood up out of his wheelchair after Roger Federer hit an unbelievable shot at the Australian Open - before he was knocked out by Serbia's Novak Djokovic.
During Thursday night's match at Rod Laver Arena in Melbourne, Federer made an impressive return hit, winning an integral point against Djokovic and causing the crowd to launch into thunderous applause.
As the camera panned over the crowd, one over-excited man was captured rising out of his wheelchair as he pumped his fist into the air in celebration.
Scroll down for video
A man has stood up out of his wheelchair (pictured in maroon shirt) after Roger Federer hit an unbelievable shot at the Australian Open
During Thursday night's match at Rod Laver Arena in Melbourne, Federer made an impressive return hit (pictured)
Social media were quick to react to the moment, with some claiming it was proof the Swiss tennis star was 'a God.'
'A guy who was sitting in a wheelchair got up to cheer for Roger Federer. That man is inspired,' one person shared on Twitter.
'OMG! Federer made a man in a wheelchair stand on his feet!' another said.
'Finally, we have the proof that Federer is God!' one woman proclaimed.
During a post-match press conference, a reporter asked where the impressive point rated on a personal scale for Federer.
'Top 100?' he responded, igniting laughs from around the room.
'But then I got unlucky so that calmed me down very fast,' Federer continued.
'It was a nice point and a great ovation. I was very happy I got as much support as I did, it was a cool moment.
'I wish I was in a better spot in the result but nevertheless, I'm happy to pull up those shots, of course.'
Djokovic was on track to dish out the heaviest hardcourt defeat of Federer's 1307-match career before the great Swiss thrilled fans at Rod Laver Arena - including Laver himself - to raise hopes of a famous comeback win.
But after a controversial 10-minute stoppage to close the roof amid forecasts of rain, Djokovic regained control to seal a spot in Sunday's night's championship decider, defeating Federer 6-1, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3.
After a controversial 10-minute stoppage to close the roof amid forecasts of rain, Djokovic regained control to seal a spot in Sunday's night's championship decider,
Djokovic (left) will play the winner of Friday night's second semi-final between Scottish world No.2 and four-time runner-up Andy Murray or big-serving Canadian 13th seed Milos Raonic
Social media were quick to react to the moment, with some claiming it was proof the Swiss tennis star was 'a God'
'Right now, I feel like I'm at the peak of my career and I'm trying to cherish every moment on court,' Djokovic said during a post-match interview
During a post-match press conference, a reporter asked where the impressive point rated on a personal scale for Federer and he responded: Top 100?
Djokovic will play the winner of Friday night's second semi-final between Scottish world No.2 and four-time runner-up Andy Murray or big-serving Canadian 13th seed Milos Raonic.
The 28-year-old will be bidding to join legends Bjorn Borg and Rod Laver with 11 major championship wins in what will be his 19th grand slam final.
'Right now, I feel like I'm at the peak of my career and I'm trying to cherish every moment on court,' Djokovic said during a post-match interview.
'Definitely I played an unbelievable first two sets but that's what is necessary against Roger.
'He's been playing a very high level in this tournament. He's been playing very aggressively.
'I came up with the right intensity. I executed everything perfectly.
'Obviously with a two-set lead is more comfortable, but it was a battle in the end.'
The crowd immediately launched into thunderous applause
As the camera panned over the crowd, one over-excited man was captured rising out of his wheelchair as he pumped his fist into the air in celebration
Social media were quick to react to the moment, with some claiming it was proof the Swiss tennis star was 'a God'
Although Federer gained some momentum toward the end of the match, Novak Djokovic (pictured) was still victorious 6-1, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3
